studdy

the app that i made in 2 weeks, just because

languages used: app-devswift
tldr: study timer app with a buddy

So I made an app in two weeks during October of 2019 because I found a random competition and I was bored. Armed with knowledge from two whole elective computer science classes, I decided why not.

One might think I only had two weeks because I procrastinated‚Äîwell, you usually wouldn‚Äôt be wrong but you are.

I found this competition during my vacation on the opposite side of the country, so I could only begin when school was starting because that‚Äôs when I was going to be back at home.

However, when school started, work and studying unsurprisingly followed. While adjusting to the new year, I kept trying to think of ideas any time I wasn‚Äôt trying to shove kinematics concepts and rhetorical analysis into my brain. Unfortunately, any semblance of creativity perished after the first month of my junior year.

That‚Äôs how an app idea related to school came to fruition‚Ä¶

I figured that maintaining focus was difficult for me so I wanted (more accurately, needed) to keep myself accountable. Hence, studdy, the mashup of the words ‚Äústudy‚Äù and ‚Äúbuddy,‚Äù became a thing because what‚Äôs better than instant gratification!

So that was the whole idea.

When I began programming, I was, as expected, lost. But after learning some basic syntax, I just sought out to fulfill my plans, which is a generous term because it was just a messy amalgamation of thoughts from lunch, study hall, and scribbles on my world history notes.

Let‚Äôs take a moment to appreciate my culture and religions notes.

Okay, enough rambling. Let‚Äôs actually get onto the thing I made because that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre here! (probably?)

demonstration of the thing i made!

here‚Äôs what you see when the app opens.

plants.

the font was custom made by yours truly. glad my handwriting became useful for once.

buy stuff because you already had coins there from a year ago.

tap on alarm clock to track how long you studied for.

try to ignore the fact that i can‚Äôt draw any poses!!!

profit.

plants won‚Äôt be lost to the void!

actual process that went into making this thing work, sort of

Originally, I thought this idea was simple enought because‚Ä¶well, I mean, it‚Äôs just a timer, some math, and wow, now you have app!

haha.

xcode yelled at me a lot

Honestly, I can‚Äôt really explain the actual process and the obstacles I encountered while making this because I don‚Äôt remember it, so I guess I‚Äôll explain some of the code that‚Äôs behind this app!

It‚Äôs currently 2 AM when I‚Äôm writing this so please excuse any poor explanations.

  • Every time the timer updates, the variable that stores time accumulates. Then, I just did some second grade math which uses that time variable to convert the time studied into coins based on a set ratio (e.g. for every 10 minutes, you earn 5 of coins).
  • When the user buys an item, it‚Äôs appended to a global objects array. This array, and the variable that contains the amount of coins the user possesses, is stored in UserDefaults. Because these values doesn‚Äôt require much data, UserDefaults is suitable to make sure the data is persistent when the app is killed. Don‚Äôt want innocent plants to get lost in some abyss.
let defaults = UserDefaults.standard

let currentCoinAmt = defaults.integer(forKey: "totalCoins") ?? 0
coinAmt = currentCoinAmt

let currentInv = defaults.array(forKey: "userInv")

if currentInv != nil {
    boughtItems = currentInv as! [String]
}
  • When the app is launched again, it sets the user‚Äôs inventory equal to what‚Äôs stored in UserDefaults. It initializes only the plants that were appended to the objects array (when they‚Äôre bought) because, well, that‚Äôs all that should be available to the user.
for plantName in boughtItems {
    let item: plantObject? = plantDict[plantName]
    let plant = showingBoughtPlants(imgname: item?.plantImgName ?? "", posx: item?.plantPosX ?? 0, posy: item?.plantPosY ?? 0, scale: item?.plantScale ?? 0, zpos: item?.plantZPos ?? 0)
    addChild(plant)
}
  • If I recall correctly, registering touches gave me a massive headache posed some difficulties. It‚Äôs a function so the UI reacts to perform what it‚Äôs supposed to. Like when a button (it‚Äôs actually an image) contains a touch from the user, it does stuff.


concluding thoughts

What would I have improved? Pretty much everything. Besides my little plants (I love my plants alright). And probably most of the shop menu graphics (kind of proud of that too).

I could sit here and just completely obliterate my app, but let‚Äôs not do that.

  • The art, even though that‚Äôs the least of concerns
  • Bugs like how the timer becomes confused after it surpasses an hour
  • Adding inventory functionality where you can store plants (I originally had this but I couldn‚Äôt get it to work properly)
  • Adding the ability for users to modify the location of the plants
  • I also wanted relaxing music (lofi hip-hop) to play while the studying session was running, but then I realized I don‚Äôt know music‚Ä¶also it was really not a necessity anyways I ran out of time
  • And most of all: code structure, organization, and efficiency. So basically, the whole entire app! The code‚Äôs pretty crude‚Ä¶but hey, that‚Äôs part of learning, am I right? *nervous chuckle*

Anyhow, even though I can‚Äôt say that I‚Äôm exceptionally proud of this project, I‚Äôm still pleased that I was able to make something completely from scratch. It gave me an oppurtunity to apply programming concepts I‚Äôve learned in and outside of class, and I got an actual feel for Swift that wasn‚Äôt mindlessly staring at tutorials. That‚Äôs about it. I hope you enjoyed reading!
